tossups.question: The Gelfand diaries are a notable primary source about rampant sexual violence in the wake of this battle, which led to a war memorial to the attacking forces becoming derisively known as the “Tomb of the Unknown Rapist.” A key defensive structure in this battle was named for its proximity to a local zoological park. Civilians during this battle were subjected to shouts of “Uri! Uri! Uri!” from soldiers demanding their (*) wristwatches, one of which appeared on Yevgeny Khaldei before being infamously edited out of an iconic photograph. This battle followed clashes at Seelow Heights and Halbe, and it ended after Felix Steiner was unable to rally enough troops for a counter-offensive against Georgy Zhukov. For 10 points, name this battle that culminated in the storming of the Reichstag by Soviet Troops in the German capital.
tossups.answer: Battle of Berlin [accept Battle in Berlin, the engagement which all these clues are about] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: “Upper” and “lower” forms of this operation are named for Dini. Darboux’s theorem states that for a function f, this operation of f maps open intervals to open intervals. The integral of a form over the boundary of a manifold is equal to the integral of the exterior type of this operation of the function over the whole manifold, according to (*) Stokes’ theorem. One theorem states that if a function evaluated at two points is equal, then this operation must equal 0 at some point between them. This operation, when applied to the composition of multiple functions, can be computed using the chain rule. For 10 points, name this operation, which in the single variable case gives the slope of the tangent to a function.

One poet from this group complains about a woman who carries “ June in her eyes, in her heart January.” Another poem by an author from this group describes a bride whose “Finger was so small, the ring / would not stay on” and “Mouth so small . . . her words did break / that they might passage get.” That author from this group wrote “Why so pale and wan fond lover?” and “Ballad upon a Wedding,” and is John (*) Suckling. Another author from this group praised the “brave vibration each way free” and the “liquefaction” of a silk dress in “Upon Julia’s Clothes,” and exhorted some girls to “Gather ye rosebuds while ye may” in “To the Virgins, to Make Much of Time.” For 10 points, name this group of Royalist 17th-century poets like Thomas Carew, Richard Lovelace and Robert Herrick, who drew inspiration from Ben Jonson.

This deity set Thea among the stars after she gave birth to Melanippe. The first trial in history occurred after Ares killed this deity’s son Halirrhothius for violating Alcippe. This deity killed the giant Polybotes after throwing the island of Kos at him. The Thracian king Eumolpus, noted for his singing ability, was the offspring of this deity and Chione. According to Eustathius, the wife of this deity was first seen dancing at Naxos, and that wife’s Roman equivalent is (*) Salacia. This deity raped Demeter, resulting in the birth of Arion. Athena beat out this god in the contest to become the patron deity in Athens, leading to a flood this husband of Amphitrite brought upon Athens in anger. This deity took revenge on Odysseus by delaying and complicating his return to Ithaca for blinding his son Polyphemus. For 10 points, name this trident-wielding Greek god of the Sea.
tossups.answer: Poseidon [do NOT accept “Neptune” after “Ares” is read] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: One object of this type, mentioned in Genesis 38, is given after the birth of the twins Zarah and Pharez.  The Guru Nanak legendarily questioned Pandit Hardyal during a ceremony involving these objects, instead requesting one for his soul. A devotion to the sun god known as the Gayatri mantra is traditionally recited before the bestowal of one of these objects, after which men are considered “dvija” or twice-born. A story about King Bali and (*) Lakshmi is one inspiration for a festival utilizing these items. 72 of these things represent the 72 chapters of the Yasna in an object granted along with the Sedreh. One of these objects called the janeu is central to the Hindu coming-of-age ritual of upanayanam, after which brahmin are required to wear one over their shoulder. For 10 points, name these objects central to Raksha bandhan, in which one of these things is tied around a sibling’s wrist.

An equation used to compare efficiencies in this technique is the Knox equation. A modification of an important equation for this technique adds dependence between terms for eddy diffusion and mass transfer, and is named for Giddings. Sephadex and sephacryl are used in one version of this technique which separates components by their (*) Stokes radius. The equation “H equals A, plus B over u, plus c U” quantifies band broadening in this technique; that equation is named for van Deemter. Large values of psi are used in the “high-performance” form of this technique, which can use packed silica as the stationary phase. For 10 points, name this technique which separates compounds based on differences in their flow rate.
tossups.answer: column chromatography [or high-performance liquid chromatography or HPLC; or size-exclusion chromatography]

tossups.question: While German ambassador to this country, Karl von Luxburg called for the destruction of this country’s ships “without a trace” and called its foreign minister a “notorious ass.” Universal compulsory voting was established in this country through the Sáenz Peña Law. The Radical Civic Union dominated its politics in the early 1900s while lead by Hipólito Yrigoyen. Julio Roca expanded this country’s territory in the Conquest of the (*) Desert. This country gained independence during the May Revolution, as commemorated by a square in its capital city. In the 1800s, it was ruled by many caudillos, including Juan Manuel de Rosas. Gauchos who raised cattle on the Pampas formed a major base of support for this country’s early military dictators. For 10 points, name home country of Jose de San Martin.

This character reveals an interest in science after he finds a biochemistry book in a carriage and tries to return it to the narrator. An alternate ending ends by remarking that there isn’t much difference between this man’s living and dead relatives, “cept down there they're all quiet, and the women have got to hold their tongues.” This “ruin of a man” is described as having “been in [the central location] too many winters” by the driver (*) Harmon Gow. This man lies about having to pick up cash from Andrew Hale to excuse himself from driving his sickly wife to the Flats. This man’s wife Zeena takes care of him and his cousin Mattie Silver after they attempt suicide by sled crash. For 10 points, name this title character of a novella by Edith Wharton.

The “Politics” of these research subjects was analyzed in a book that said human behavior can not be fully explained by selfishness and Darwinian forces. A book by Wrangham and Peterson analyzes the presence of “extreme patriarchal structures” in these subjects. Instead of trial-and-error, these subjects exhibit insight when solving problems according to a book published after a six-year research study on the island of Tenerife. Like humans, these subjects studied by (*) Frans de Waal exhibit the “demonic male” phenomenon. Wolfgang Kohler’s The Mentality of Apes is about these animals, which led him to theorize a fluid divide between humans and animals. One researcher studied these animals and their use of tools at the Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania. For 10 points, Jane Goodall studied what primates that are the closest living relatives to humans?
tossups.answer: Chimpanzees [prompt on “apes” before “The Mentality of Apes” is read but definitely do not prompt on “monkeys”] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: A C minor piano sonata by this composer begins with fermata on both hands playing octave Gs before the right hand plays B, C, D, D, D. A piano four hands work by this composer begins with the secondo playing unison D, A, A, G sharp, A twice. A work by this composer, which begins with repeated C major chords, is so hard that this composer said that “the devil may play it.” A symphony by this composer was described as having a (*) “heavenly length” by another composer. This composer’s Six Moments Musicaux are often paired with his two sets of impromptus. This composer’s two C-major symphonies were given the titles “Little” and “Great,” and he opted for the use of a double bass instead of a second violin in his Trout Quintet. For 10 points, which composer left his B-minor 8th symphony unfinished?

One writer who lived in this city was sent there to work in a factory which his father had established with Peter Ermen. A publication founded in this city was established by the “Little Circle,” including John Edward Taylor; that newspaper is today owned by a trust established by John Scott. This city is the home of its country’s oldest free public library, Chetham’s Library, where Karl (*) Marx and Friedrich Engels conducted research. Engels wrote The Condition of the Working Class in England while living in this city, based in part on his observations of its industry. The Peterloo massacre took place in this city, where The Guardian was founded. For 10 points, identify this city, once the world center of the textile industry, which is today at the center of the second-largest metro area in Britain.

In To the Finland Station, Edmund Wilson attributes the impact of this story upon Lenin to the fact that it “serves as a fable of the situation of the frustrated intellectuals . . . of the eighties and nineties.” The main character of this story planned to become a priest, until his father threatened to disown him. That character in this story reads for six hours every night and uses stoic principles to explain suffering to a person in the title location of this story, which is surrounded by weeds and guarded by the brutal (*) Nikita. The main character of this story comes back from a forced holiday to discover that his job has been taken by Khobotov, who tricks him into entering the title location for good. For 10 points, name this story in which doctor Andrey Ragin is shut up in the asylum he used to work in, written by Anton Chekhov.

One painting by this artist contains a creature with multi-colored concentric circles on its wings, which may have inspired John Tenniel’s depiction of the Jabberwock. This artist painted four men with halos for the facade of a seven-foot wide clock with a gold star at its centre. Another work by this artist in the same building depicts an English mercenary on horseback. This artist, who decorated the Duomo with his Funerary Monument to Sir John (*) Hawkwood, pioneered linear perspective in a painting which shows many people, horses, and dogs disappearing into the darkness. This artist of The Hunt in the Forest painted Micheletto da Cotignola on a black horse about to lead his troops into battle in another work. For 10 points, name this Florentine artist who created a set of paintings depicting The Battle of San Romano.
tossups.answer: Paolo Uccello [accept Paolo di Dono] <Ed. DS>

tossups.question: This character tries to donate money towards a man’s burial, but is rejected until it is revealed whose money it is. After the undertaker agrees to bury that man despite insufficient money, this character begins singing "Oh, the train is at the station." During a hurricane, after the aria "Oh there's somebody knocking at the door," another character barges in seeking this character. After a picnic, that character had earlier forced this woman into the woods, causing her to miss a boat back from (*) Kittiwah Island. A dealer of "Happy Dust" repeatedly offers to take this character to New York. This character runs off with Sportin’ Life, a fact which a disabled beggar learns after singing an aria asking where this character is; that other character vows to leave Catfish Row in order to find this woman. For 10 points, name this George Gershwin character who is desired by Porgy.

A society of working-class immigrants from this country was analyzed in a 1910 article in the American Historical Review by James Ford Rhodes, the man who won the second Pulitzer Prize for History. A group made up of immigrants from this country called themselves the Roach Guards and used a dead rabbit as their symbol. The Battle of Ridgeway began along the the United States’ northern border after an organization of immigrants from this country (*) raided Canada while they were led by John O’Neill. Many immigrants from this country allied with “Boss” Tweed’s Tammany Hall machine and settled in Hell’s Kitchen. Immigrants from this country created the Fenian Brotherhood and the Molly Maguires. For 10 points, name this European country, whose immigrants came to the United States en masse while fleeing a potato famine.
tossups.answer: Ireland [or Eire; or the Irish Free State; or people from Ireland; or Irish people] <JO>

tossups.question: The “magnetic” form of this effect occurs with circularly polarized photons, and is used to measure magnetic moments in ferromagnetic materials. Crude measurements of the fine structure constant can be made via this effect, since a key length in this process is related to the classical electron radius by a factor of alpha. The finite amount of energy transferred by this process leads to its namesake (*) “edge” in spectroscopy. A so-called “inverse” form of this process distorts the CMB and is named for Sunyaev and Zel’dovich. The differential cross-section of this phenomenon is given by the Klein-Nishina formula. The quantity “h over m sub e times c” is the wavelength associated with this effect. For 10 points, name this inelastic scattering of a photon off an electron, named for a British physicist.

One installment of this franchise has a series of missions which involve helping your neighbors and includes the main character while serving as best man at a local wedding. DLC for another installment of this franchise introduces the blunderbuss and has the main character work with a local brothel owner to help the Maroons. This franchise released a short film which saw the death of a prominent character and hinted at future games set in China. That film released by this franchise was subtitled (*) “Embers.” Collectibles in this franchise include war letters, feathers, and fragments. One character from this franchise seduces Catarina Sforza, befriends Leonardo Da Vinci, and kills Cesare Borgia, all in the process of avenging his family. For 10 points, which video game franchise follows characters such as Arno Dorian, Edward Kenway, and Ezio Auditore?

This country is represented as a mouse-deer in a comic explaining this country’s history via talking animals. That comic was created by a fictional artist named Charlie, as part of a 2015 graphic novel from this country. A novel set in this country has a title alluding to a sexual technique and follows the adventures of naive Matthew Webb; that novel is the final installment in the Empire trilogy. This non-China country is the setting of Sonny Liew’s The Art of Charlie Chan Hock Chye and J.G. Farrell’s The [this country] Grip. A 2013 comedy of manners about an NYU professor named Rachel (*) Chu, who goes to this country for a wedding, is packed with references to expensive designer-name brands. For 10 points, name this setting of Kevin Kwan’s Crazy Rich Asians, which has one of the highest GDPs-per-capita in the world.

In 2012, Ehud Gazit’s lab showed that this disease could result amyloid-like plaques formed by what at the time was the smallest known individual subunit of those plaques. PEG-PAL has been a suggested gene to use in gene therapy approaches to this disease. High doses of sapropterin can lead to improved outcomes of this disease as it acts as a cofactor for the primary enzyme deficient in this disease. This disease can lead to a (*) “mousy” odor on the skin. Dietary considerations in this disease include the consumption of foods high in glycomacropeptide and giving Lofenalac to newborns, which can result in this disease having almost no symptoms. This disease is most commonly caused by the inability to produce tyrosine from a defective PAH gene. For 10 points, name this disease in which the body is unable to break down phenylalanine.

Harry Frankfurt's 2007 book partly titled for "Dreamers and Madmen" is a defense of this book. In this text, its author claims that the senses are not meant to give information about the “essential nature” of objects. The fifth section of this work contains a supposedly original version of the (*) ontological argument that is non-discursive and is instead intuitive. Ryle’s phrase “ghost in the machine” was created to characterize a belief first advocated in this text. This book proposes an “evil demon” that could trick someone to believe anything. The author of this work uses that argument to motivate his methodological scepticism. For 10 points, name this text in which the author claims to argue for the immortality of the soul by arguing for God’s existence and the separation of mind and body, a work by Descartes.

(TB) One defeat of this country’s forces is credited to the intervention of the “Black Madonna,” whose icon was endangered during a siege by this country’s troops. This country’s troops were defeated by a small force led by a group of monks during that battle at the Jasna Gora Monastery. One leader of this country had his troops march across two frozen straits in order to attack a neighboring country in the “March Across the (*) Belts,” which led to the Treaty of Roskilde. This country’s invasion of Poland marked the beginning of the Deluge. This country had emerged as a major power after an earlier war which saw its troops win a victory at Lutzen, even as its king was killed there. For 10 points, identify this country, which was ruled by Charles X Gustav and Gustavus Adolphus.
tossups.answer: Sweden [or the Swedish Empire] <Ed. JM> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name some authors who also wrote lyrics to popular music.
parts: This novelist contributed lyrics to Mark Ronson’s album Uptown Special, but is better known for writing The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Klay and The Yiddish Policeman’s Union.
This author wrote lyrics for Ben Folds’ album Lonely Avenue. He knows music quite well, having written the novel High Fidelity.
This American poet appears as a guest vocalist on The Clash’s song “Ghetto Defendant.” He recited a Buddhist sutra at the end of the song, reflecting his practice of that religion.

bonuses.leadin: In the wake of this conflict, the Sisters of the Holy Names of Jesus and Mary angrily sued governor Walter Pierce about a xenophobically-motivated Oregon law banning private education. For 10 points each:
answers: World War I [or the Great War]
Creel Committee [accept Committee for Public Information or Creel Commission or CPI] <Ed. JM>
parts: Identify this conflict, which the U.S. entered in 1917.

The decision in the Pierce case was written by this man, a member of the conservative “Four Horseman,” who is best known for being a virulent racist and anti-Semite who refused to acknowledge Louis Brandeis’s existence.

Several World War I-era Supreme Court cases, including Schenck v. US and Abrams V. US, centered on the distribution of anti-war pamphlets. This governmental body named for a Colorado journalist coordinated a massive effort to distribute pro-war pamphlets and speeches.

bonuses.leadin: In the scene after this one, a character played by Uma Thurman overdoses on heroin before being saved by a needle of adrenaline to the heart. For 10 points each:
answers: the dancing scene in Pulp Fiction [accept answers such as Vincent Vega and Mia Wallace dancing; or twisting; or scene at Jack Rabbit Slim’s, but don’t mention the name of the restaurant]
parts: Name this scene, which depicts a certain action between two characters at a 1950s themed restaurant. The two characters in this scene are at the restaurant because Marsellus Wallace is out of town.
The dancing scene in Pulp Fiction occurs at this restaurant.
The song playing during the dance, “You Never Can Tell,” was recorded by this artist, who died in 2017.

bonuses.leadin: William Blake asked whether this city was “builded here / among these dark Satanic Mills” in a poem that begins “And did those feet in ancient time.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, which is “Delivered” in an epic poem that fictionalizes the First Crusade.
Jerusalem Delivered was written by this sixteenth-century Italian poet. This author’s seven years in St. Anna’s were commemorated in a Eugene Delacroix painting of this man in the Madhouse.

This poet described walking “from one epoch to another without a memory to guide [him]” while “within the ancient walls” of Jerusalem in one poem. His “Identity Card” begins “Write down! / I am an Arab.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Terra Preta do Indio, a weirdly productive type of soil. For 10 points each,
parts: Terra Preta is found in this river’s basin. This river receives tributaries such as the Araguaia and Xingu [Shin-goo], and it contains the world’s largest rainforest.

Terra Preta do Indio, as its name implies, is black, which marks it as distinct from this soil order that surrounds it. This soil order is known for its high kaolinite content, which, along with other minerals, renders it red. It covers most tropical and subtropical regions.

Terra Preta do Indio derives most of its fertility from pre-Columbian peoples who integrated this, along with potsherds and feces, into soil. This substance is the darker colored of the two by-products of swidden agriculture.

bonuses.leadin: After the Charlie Hebdo shooting, Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo threatened legal action against Fox News for using this term for various Banlieues in France. For 10 points each:
answers: No-Go Zones [prompt on slums or other imprecise answers]
parts: Give this colloquial term, which denotes areas with high crime and low state involvement, most frequently used by nativists to describe areas that supposedly enforce Sharia.

Various fake news websites have claimed this Michigan city west of Detroit was a No-Go Zone and was “rumored” to be governed by Sharia law. This city has the highest population of Arab Americans in the US, and is home to the River Rouge Ford plant.

The original Fox News article also erroneously claimed this UK city had No-Go Zones in it. This city, home of the Highgate Muslim neighborhood, had four people arrested in 2016 here in connection with the Paris attacks.

bonuses.leadin: This dynasty ruled the Emirate of Ha’il, or Jabal Shammar, in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this royal dynasty, which conquered the Emirate of Nejd in 1891 after the Battle of Mulayda.

At the time of the Rashidi conquest, Nejd had been controlled by a member of this man’s family. This man succeeded in retaking Riyadh and establishing a new kingdom there, which bears his family’s name.

After defeating the Rashidis, Ibn Saud launched a war against the Kingdom of Hejaz, which controlled the city of Mecca and was ruled by this other family, which is better known today for controlling Jordan.

bonuses.leadin: When the title character of this play is approached by Death, he offers it a thousand pounds to go away, but Death refuses. For 10 points,
parts: Identify this anonymously written play, whose hero discovers that the only one who can come with him to heaven is the personified character Good Deeds. Its name has become the standard term for a protagonist who almost anyone can identify with.

Everyman is an example of this genre, in which characters representing abstract concepts try to win the protagonists over to a life of virtue. Other fifteenth-century examples of this genre include Mankind, Wisdom and The Castle of Perseverance, which were all found in the Macro Manuscript.

A modernized version of Everyman was created by this author, whose poems are collected in The World’s Wife. This author was appointed Poet Laureate of the UK in 2009 and as of 2017 still holds the position.

bonuses.leadin: A tribalistic depiction of this character shows his many arms clutching a framed collage in a work in which this character "introduces" himself. for 10 points each:
parts: Name this “superior of birds,” who also appears in some of his creator’s "collage novels." This character may have been inspired by an incident in its creator’s childhood where he learned about the death of his parrot and the birth of his sister within minutes of each other.

Loplop was created by this German artist of Two Children are Menaced by a Nightingale. This inventor of the “frottage” and “grattage” techniques used a suction method called “decalcomania” to paint Europe After the Rain.
Loplop pokes his head over a canvas in an Ernst collage where he "Presents Members" of this art movement, which included Ernst himself. The work includes depictions of Luis Bunuel and Salvador Dali.

bonuses.leadin: This theorist developed the idea of the “focal point” in his book The Strategy of Conflict. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Nobel Prize-winning game theorist known for his work on brinkmanship. Both he and Henry Kissinger worked for the RAND Corporation during the Cold War.

Schelling is known for his contributions to the theory of deterrence for these weapons. Herman Kahn applied game theory to analyze a kind of war characterized by the use of these extremely destructive weapons.

Like Schelling, this author of Superforecasting won an NAS award for research into preventing nuclear war. This current University of Pennsylvania professor wrote about hedgehogs and foxes in a book that questions expert political judgement.

bonuses.leadin: These reactions typically require a strong base, such as sodium ethoxide, and occur on primary and secondary carbons. For 10 points each;
parts: Name this class of reactions, in which an alkene is formed in one step through a bimolecular mechanism.
E2 reactions require the carbon-leaving group bond and hydrogen-carbon bond have this orientation-relative configuration. The dihedral angle in this configuration is 180 degrees.
This very strong leaving group is also called p-toluenesulfonate. This compound is formed by the substitution of a chloride with an alcohol on its central sulfur atom.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some things about the technical methods of 20th-century German composer Karlheinz Stockhausen. For 10 points each:
parts: Stockhausen was best known for utilizing this technique, an extension of Schoenberg's twelve-tone row, in which many aspects of a composition, such as its timbre or dynamics, were determined by sequences.
Stockhausen was a pioneer in this broad genre of music, which includes instruments such as the theremin and the synthesizer. This type of music can produce sounds using artificial waveforms.

In his Gesang der Jünglinge, Stockhausen blended electronic music with a Pierre Schaeffer-developed style, also used by Edgar Varese and Pierre Boulez, whose compositions involve manipulating pre-recorded sounds. That technique is named for this man-made substance.

bonuses.leadin: In preparation for his film adaptation of this author’s best-known novel, Emir Kusturica built an entire village named after this man. For 10 points,
parts: Name this Serbian-language author and diplomat who chronicled his home country’s history through the title structure in his novel The Bridge on the Drina.
Andrić worked as a diplomat for this former country, which made The Bridge on the Drina mandatory reading in schools from its release in 1945 until this country’s dissolution in 1992.

Another Yugoslav book with a stone structure in its name is this collection by Danilo Kis. In its title story, Fedukin interrogates a revolutionary who seems not to fear death, but does fear that his biography will be distorted.

bonuses.leadin: Appropriately, the name of this technique simply means “billboard” in Japanese. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique, which uses namesake cards to control the flow of inventory in a manufacturing system. This technique has also been adopted for project management.
Kanban and other lean manufacturing techniques were developed at this company, the world’s largest automobile manufacturer. This company’s products include the Camry.

This other popular technique for manufacturing process improvement focuses on statistical analysis. It aims to identify factors which are critical to quality in order to achieve the namesake level of passing products.

bonuses.leadin: Answer these questions about short-reigning world leaders, for 10 points each:
parts: Luis Felipe became Portugal’s king for about 30 minutes while bleeding out in a carriage, where he had been shot along with this king, his father. This man was the first Portuguese monarch killed in office since Sebastian.

Siaka Stevens had just been sworn in as Prime Minister of this country a few minutes before when rebels burst into his office and deposed him, though he later led it for 15 years. Its capital is Freetown.

Carlos Manuel Piedra very briefly held power in 1959 after the fall of this man, who operated the BRAC secret police and was nicknamed “El Indio” for his Taino ancestry. Eduardo Chibas shot himself live on radio after failing to expose this man’s corruption.

bonuses.leadin: The QRS complex indicates the beginning of the ventricular contraction associated with this phase. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phase where the heart pushes blood to the rest of the body, contrasted with diastole.
This collection of muscle cells connects the AV node to the Purkinje fibres. It is named for a Swiss physician.
The cardiac cycle can be visualized using this diagram, which plots key quantities like blood pressure, volume, and EKG read-out against time to show how these quantities correlate over the cycle.

bonuses.leadin: One example of these events occurred when physicists stopped using Newtonian Mechanics in favour of the theories of Einstein and of quantum mechanics. For 10 points each:
answers: modus tollendo tollens [prompt on denying the consequent and other close translations] <Ed. HB>
parts: Name these events, described in The Structure of Scientific Revolutions.
This American author was partially inspired by Michael Polanyi to write The Structure of Scientific Revolutions.

In partial contrast with Kuhn’s paradigm shifts, Popper’s theory of falsification uses logic based on this two-word Latin phrase, that is often contrasted with modus ponens. This method allows Popper to argue only that a prediction is false--not that a theory is true.

bonuses.leadin: You are a medieval European who wants to get in shape. Maybe some of these doctors can help you. For 10 points each:
parts: You first decide to try the wine, bread, and mushroom-heavy diet recommended by a rhyming text put out by this Italian city’s pioneering medical school. This city’s time under Arabic control and location near the library of Monte Cassino gave it unique access to knowledge about medicine.

You tried the Salerno diet. It didn’t work. You move on to the helpful recipes in the Lorch Book of Medicine, which was put out by monks from this modern country, also the native country of Albertus Magnus, a native of Cologne.

After the Lorch Book also fails you, you ask your local doctor what’s wrong. He refers to the Compendium of Medicine in Seven Books put out by this 7th century Byzantine surgeon, who traveled to Alexandria to study ancient medical texts.

bonuses.leadin: The scene featuring these objects follows after some angels reap the earth with sickles and cast a winepress into "the vine of the earth," causing blood to come out. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, which are given to seven angels. The first of these objects causes a "grievous sore" to men with the mark of the beast, while the last causes a voice to say "It is done" before a great earthquake.
This final book of the New Testament features the pouring of the seven vials, as well as the messages to the Seven Churches of Asia. It was probably written by John on the island of Patmos.

In Revelation, the letter to this city’s church praises their works, labor, and patience, but criticizes that they have "left their first love." A Pauline epistle to this city states “For it is by grace you have been saved, through faith.”

bonuses.leadin: Like other waveguides, these devices may be either singlemode or multimode. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these waveguides, which confine light through total internal reflection.
Multimode optical fibres are cheaper and easier to use, but suffer from attenuation due to this effect, where different modes propagate at different speeds, distorting the signal.
In conventional metallic closed waveguides, this mode cannot propagate due to the boundary conditions on the waveguide. This is the mode of propagation in free space.
